articles.headline: Nokia Does a Map Deal, Signaling Strategic Bet
articles.snippet: Nokia is buying Navteq, the maker of digital mapping and navigational software, for $8.1 billion, as it seeks to migrate location services onto its range of phones.
articles.abstract: Nokia is buying Navteq, the maker of digital mapping and navigational software, for $8.1 billion, as it seeks to migrate location services onto its range of phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nokia’s plans to acquire the map and navigational software maker Navteq for $8.1 billion raise the stakes in the competition among wireless carriers, handset makers and new entrants like Google and Microsoft to deliver information and advertising directly to cellphone users.

articles.headline: Write-Downs by Big Banks Spark Rally
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s banking giants started to admit their problems, and investors took the disclosures as a sign that the worst may be over.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s banking giants started to admit their problems, and investors took the disclosures as a sign that the worst may be over.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s banking giants started yesterday to admit their problems, which began in the mortgage lending business and led to a summer of wild stock market swings.

articles.headline: Stocks Soar on Hopes Credit Crisis Is Over
articles.snippet: Investors bought back into the banking and housing sectors today, pushing the Dow average up 1.4 percent to close at 14,087.55.
articles.abstract: Investors bought back into the banking and housing sectors today, pushing the Dow average up 1.4 percent to close at 14,087.55.
articles.lead_paragraph: Blue-chip stocks pushed into record territory yesterday as investors seemed to shrug off this summer’s problems with subprime mortgage lending. At least for now.

articles.headline: Some Banks in Europe Suffer, Too
articles.snippet: The loss underscored the extent to which some of Europe’s largest financial institutions are exposed to investments that rest on shaky American mortgages.
articles.abstract: The loss underscored the extent to which some of Europe’s largest financial institutions are exposed to investments that rest on shaky American mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Oct. 1  Europe’s biggest bank, UBS, has become the Continent’s biggest casualty of the American mortgage crisis, reporting Monday that it had written down $3.4 billion in the value of mortgage-backed securities and would post a loss in the third quarter.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Putin Says He Will Run for Parliament
articles.snippet: The suggestion seemed to confirm that President Vladimir V. Putin plans to hold on to the power he has accrued.
articles.abstract: The suggestion seemed to confirm that President Vladimir V. Putin plans to hold on to the power he has accrued.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 1 — President Vladimir V. Putin, who is barred from seeking another term, suggested Monday that he might become prime minister next year, seeming to confirm what many analysts had assumed: that he plans to hold on to the power he has accrued over eight years.

articles.headline: For the Yachting Class, the Latest Amenity Can Take Flight
articles.snippet: Many among the rich or famous want a yacht, and what buyers want most now are accessories: minisubmarines and helicopters.
articles.abstract: Many among the rich or famous want a yacht, and what buyers want most now are accessories: minisubmarines and helicopters.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONACO — Massimo Vilardi, an executive with Eurocopter, came to this year’s Monaco yacht show to sell helicopters.

articles.headline: Fair Trade in Bloom
articles.snippet: Corporations are rushing to meet the demand for food products that meet social and environmental standards.
articles.abstract: Corporations are rushing to meet the demand for food products that meet social and environmental standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: VARGINHA, Brazil — Rafael de Paiva was skeptical at first. If he wanted a “fair trade” certification for his coffee crop, the Brazilian farmer would have to adhere to a long list of rules on pesticides, farming techniques, recycling and other matters. He even had to show that his children were enrolled in school.
